Factors That Affect Sorting by Price on the Product List Page

Prices that buyers see on your storefront depend on several data sources and buyer experience decisions, which can complicate the task of sorting products by price. Consider the buyer's entitlements, the buyer's selected Product List page options, and the configuration settings you specify for the Product List page experience. When a buyer sorts results on the Product List page by price, B2B Commerce for Visualforce evaluates these different factors to make sure that results sort correctly.

REQUIRED EDITIONS
Salesforce CompatibilitySalesforce not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.


B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)
Sort by Entitled Price, from Low to High

Consider a simple scenario as an example:

A buyer's search returns eight (8) results on the Product List page.
The buyer sorts results from low price to high price.
The selected page size is 5.

In general, B2B Commerce for Visualforce takes the following steps to sort these results for the buyer:

B2B Commerce for Visualforce queries the first five products—the selected page size—sorted from lowest to highest indexed price.
NOTE The source of each product's indexed price depends on which product index strategy you're using.
Before showing any results on the Product List page, B2B Commerce for Visualforce finds the buyer's entitled price for the five products.
NOTE Most likely, the buyer's entitled price for each product isn't the same as the product's indexed price, regardless of your product index strategy. So, sorting results by only indexed price doesn't necessarily fulfill the buyer's selected sort experience.
On the storefront, the first page of results shows the first five products, sorted from lowest to highest entitled price.
When the buyer advances to the next page of results, B2B Commerce for Visualforce queries the three remaining products, sorted from lowest to highest indexed price.
B2B Commerce for Visualforce finds the buyer's entitled price for the three remaining products.
On the storefront, the second page of results shows the three remaining products, sorted from lowest to highest entitled price.

In this example, it works out nicely that the three remaining products with the highest indexed prices also had the highest entitled prices. The buyer's experience navigating from the first page (five results) to the second page (three remaining results) is smooth. All the results sort correctly by the buyer's entitled price.

Impact of Significant Differences Between Indexed Price and Entitled Price

Most B2B Commerce solutions have more complicated pricing scenarios. What happens when entitled prices don't conveniently sort to fit the buyer's selected page size?

Consider the same example, but with one difference: now, Product F has an entitled price of $5 instead of $80.

As before, B2B Commerce for Visualforce queries the first five products—the selected page size—sorted from lowest to highest indexed price.
Again, B2B Commerce for Visualforce finds the buyer's entitled price for the five products.
On the storefront, the Product List page shows the five products—the selected page size—sorted from lowest to highest entitled price.
When the buyer advances to the next page of results, B2B Commerce for Visualforce queries the three remaining products, sorted from lowest to highest indexed price.
B2B Commerce for Visualforce finds the buyer's entitled price for the three remaining products. In this case, the buyer's entitled price for Product F is $5—lower than the entitled price for any product on the first page.
On the storefront, the second page of results shows the three remaining products, sorted from lowest to highest entitled price. Product F sorts to the beginning of the second page because it has the lowest entitled price out of the three products.

As a result, the buyer's search experience is poor: the product that matched the buyer's search and had the lowest entitled price doesn't appear until the second page of results.

Impact of Buffer Size on Sorting by Entitled Price

Buyers expect that their specified sorting criteria always returns the correct results, and not every buyer is willing to click through multiple pages of results. In the previous example, if the buyer had selected a page size of 10, then all eight results sort correctly by entitled price. But, you can't always control the exact conditions in which a buyer uses your storefront. To guard against a potentially poor buyer experience, you can specify a buffer size: how many extra results—in addition to the selected page size—to sort by indexed price and fetch entitled prices for.

Let's revisit the previous example, but this time, you've specified a buffer size of three.

B2B Commerce for Visualforce queries all eight products—the selected page size plus buffer size—sorted from lowest to highest indexed price.
B2B Commerce for Visualforce finds the buyer's entitled price for all eight products.
On the storefront, the first page of results shows the first five products, sorted from lowest to highest entitled price.
The second page of results shows the three remaining products, sorted from lowest to highest entitled price.

For the buyer, all eight products sort correctly by entitled price, regardless of the page size they selected.

WARNING Increasing the number of entitled products that the Product List page loads—Page Size plus Buffer Size—can affect the performance and responsiveness of the page. Increasing Page Size, Buffer Size, or both can have a measurable impact on your page load times and page performance. To find the appropriate balance between performance and sorting accuracy, adjust your Page Size and Buffer Size values to stay within the following guidelines:
Try to limit the total number of products that the Product List page loads and sorts by entitled price at one time to 500 or fewer. In other words, try to limit the combined total values of the Page Size and Buffer Size configurations to less than 500.
At most, the Product List page can load and sort 1,000 products—Page Size plus Buffer Size—at one time.
